awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Confocal Microscope for Student-Faculty Research and Research Training
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Oberlin College to support the acquisition of a confocal microscope for use by faculty from Oberlin's Biology, Chemistry & Biochemistry, and Neuroscience Departments and by faculty at other institutions in the region. The confocal system will advance undergraduate training through mentored research and expansion of course-based research. The increased ease of use and robustness of the requested confocal will greatly expand Oberlin's ability to support student use in individually mentored research and in curricular offerings, while the higher scan speed, greater sensitivity, and addition of environmental control will enhance data collection.  Science education at Oberlin will therefore be enhanced by the improved activity and productivity of individual faculty research programs. Access to up-to-date instrumentation is essential to prepare students for careers in scientific research, and Oberlin College faculty will incorporate the new confocal system into four upper-level investigative laboratory courses as well as mentored research where broadening participation of under-represented student groups is particularly emphasized.
 
Modern confocal microscopy systems improve the types and quality of data that researchers can obtain and expand the range of research questions faculty can undertake. Oberlin researchers will use the system to gain deeper insight into developmental and biochemical processes through analysis of the mechanisms leading to organ initiation and spacing in plants, regulation of a proton mediated cell-cell signaling event in C. elegans, embryo formation in marsupials, immune responses to intracellular bacterial pathogens, and a range of neuroscience topics. Data and analyses from these studies will be published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, presented at scientific meetings, and used in both educational and public outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF MRI award enabled the acquisition of a fluorescent confocal microscope for imaging living cells and fixed tissue with sub-cellular resolution. This instrument is commonly used in advanced biomedical research and having a confocal microscope has enhanced scientific training at Oberlin College (Oberlin, OH), and in northeast Ohio by fostering collaboration between institutions in the area. The confocal microscope has been incorporated into the teaching curriculum and has become integral to faculty research at Oberlin College, as well as Baldwin Wallace University (Berea, OH) and Kenyon College (Gambier, OH). Further, this instrument is enabling advancement of our understanding of the brain, plant biology, and bacterial biofilms, advancing scientific understanding across a wide range of scientific fields. The microscope (Zeiss LSM 880 with 34 ch + Airyscan Fast) was installed in the Science Center at Oberlin College on March 18, 2019.

At Oberlin College, the confocal has been incorporated in the laboratory components of three upper-level undergraduate courses. Many students have used the confocal for independent or honors research projects, advancing knowledge while gaining experience with advanced instrumentation they are likely to encounter in graduate school and scientific careers. This confocal has also proven to be an effective tool for attracting students to science research. The microscope was showcased at Oberlin's 2019 laboratory open house emphasizing the breadth of collaborative student-faculty research at Oberlin and opportunities to join a research lab. The confocal was also used by students during an immersive Winter (January) Term research project for Oberlin undergraduates from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences, and it was used by students taking the International Baccalaureate Biology class at Oberlin's public high school in a week-long laboratory project. This was a highly popular activity, fostering student enthusiasm for biological research by allowing them to see cells up close and in high detail. These activities are encouraging young people in the Oberlin community to study science by giving them hands-on experience with a cutting-edge scientific instrument and technique.

To date, seven Oberlin faculty, as well as faculty from Baldwin Wallace and Kenyon, have used the confocal in their research, with the new instrument supporting a broader range of experiments and higher-quality imaging. Data from the confocal were included in a scientific article on the relationships between brain circuity and behavior, and results of two other projects investigating sub-cellular changes in the brains of an animal model system were presented at international professional meetings including the Society for Neuroscience (2019, 2021), Winter Conference on Brain Research (2020, 2022), and Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (2021). Manuscripts for three additional scientific papers on biological investigations made using the confocal are currently under peer review. One explores the impact of the neurotransmitter dopamine on brain regions that form inflexible habits, which are implicated in diseases including drug addiction. The second explores the genetic underpinnings of bacterial biofilm formation, the process by which bacteria aggregate and adhere to surfaces. Students presented this work at the April 2021 American Society for Chemistry and Biochemistry meeting. The third reports on factors that regulate the growth and development of plant root systems, an area with potential implications for agriculture. Oberlin is committed to continuing to utilize this instrument to advance knowledge in biomedical sciences, advance student training in northeast Ohio, and to increase minority representation in STEM fields.
